Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity and non-rigidity of commutative algebraic actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project lies in the area of dynamical systems and also involves number theory. The main objects are algebraic actions on tori and other homogeneous spaces by higher-rank commutative groups. The studies of such actions have contributed signi cantly to advances both in dynamical sytems and in Diophantine approximations. This research aims to investigate rigidity of these systems, a phenomenon characterized by the scarcity of invariant objects under the action. The main goal is to shed light on how higher-rank, hyperbolicity and irreducibility, the three typical conditions required in order for an action to enjoy rigidity, balance among themselves and quantitatively a ffect rigidity properties.

The field of dynamical system studies long-term trajectories of points evolving over time according to certain given rules. Having its origin in Newton's mechanical laws, the subject has found numerous applications in physics, biology, economics and other sciences. The proposed research will focus on dynamical systems of arithmetic nature. In other words, the rules of evolution can be characterized by a set of integers and rational numbers. By studying dynamical behaviors of such systems, one expects to discover number-theoretical properties. This work also seeks to strengthen the connections between ergodic theory, number theory, Lie groups, Fourier analysis and additive combinatorics by combining methods from these mathematical branches. The PI intends to develop expository notes, as well as to teach graduate-level courses on relevant topics during the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sponsored research was in the mathematical domain of dynamical systems. The field of dynamical systems originated from the study of the movement of planets and in general studies the movements of a point in a space governed by a given set of rules. This project focused on dynamical systems of group actions, in other words when the possible moves satisfy certain relations between them and therefore form a group. Roughly speaking, the acting group is said to be of higher rank, if it contains many elements that commute with each other. In such case, very often the action is expected to have rigidity. The PI studied two different kinds of higher rank group actions during the sponsored period: actions by higher rank abelian groups and those by higher rank lattices.

For higher rank abelian groups, the funded research studied their actions on nilmanifolds by automorphisms and obtained measure rigidity under a positive entropy assumption. Measure rigidity means that there are very few invariant measures, i.e. distributions of mass that are preserved by the movements, and they are all of algebraic nature. A joint work with F. Rodriguez Hertz also established smooth rigidity for Anosov actions. Smooth rigidity stands for the scarcity of ways for a given group to act in a smooth manner. It was shown that smooth Anosov actions by higher rank abelian group actions on infranilmanifolds are of algebraic nature. This confirms a conjecture of Katok and Spatzier in the infranilmanifolds.

A collaboration with A. Brown and F. Rodriguez Hertz also treated higher rank lattice actions and answered some questions from the Zimmer program. Under a mild topological condition, smooth Anosov actions by higher rank abelian group actions on nilmanifolds are also proved to be of algebraic nature. Moreover in many cases, for example when the action is Anosov or of low dimension, it was proved that an invariant measure exists.

Part of the funded research focused on the relation between dynamical rigidity and number theory. A joint paper with U. Shapira applied rigidity properties to computational number theory. Another more recent work of the PI used uniform rigidity property to prove Mobius disjointness conjecture, a question that characterizes the randomness of distribution of prime numbers, in the case of certain skew product dynamics.

During the funded period, the PI spoke at various seminars and conferences to disseminate the ideas developed in the research to the mathematical community. The PI served as the co-advisor of two graduate students, both working on rigidity properties of actions by large groups. The PI also gave seminar talks on related research topics to undergraduate audiences on multiple occasions.
